title: 103_hr2580
content: The Act titled "Federal Facilities Clean Water Compliance Act of 1993" applies certain provisions to federal facilities. Section 313(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (33 U.S.C. 1323(a)) is amended to include all administrative orders, penalties, and fines, with the United States waiving any immunity for such requirements. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include administrative orders, penalties, and fines, with the United States waiving immunity. Agents, employees, or officers of the United States are not personally liable for civil penalties under water pollution laws for acts within their official duties. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act amends to include administrative orders, penalties, and fines, with the United States waiving immunity. Agents, employees, or officers of the United States are not personally liable for criminal sanctions under water pollution laws. SEC. 3. FEDERAL FACILITY ENFORCEMENT. Section 309 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include Federal Facility Enforcement, allowing the Administrator to issue compliance orders to federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities found in violation of specific sections or permit conditions of the Act. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act's Section 309 is amended to include Federal Facility Enforcement, allowing the Administrator to issue compliance orders to federal departments, agencies, or instrumentalities found violating specific sections or permit conditions. The Secretary of the Army or the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard operates can also determine violations in permits issued under section 404 of the Act. The Administrator or Secretary may propose an order to assess a civil penalty for violations of Section 311 of the Act or its implementing regulations. The order may require immediate compliance or within a specified time period, and may include suspension or revocation of permits issued under sections 402 and 404 of the Act. The order may include suspension or revocation of permits issued under section 404 of the Act and state the violation with specificity. The penalty for each violation shall not exceed $25,000 per day. If a Federal agency requests a public hearing within 30 days, it shall be conducted in accordance with section 554 of title 5, United States Code. The Administrator or Secretary may issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents in proceedings. Failure to comply with orders may result in a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per day and permit suspension or revocation. The Administrator or Secretary may issue subpoenas for witnesses and documents in proceedings. Failure to comply with orders may result in a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per day and permit suspension or revocation. The Secretary of the Army may also suspend or revoke permits issued under section 404 of this Act. In determining the penalty amount, seriousness of violations, economic benefit, history of violations, good-faith efforts, and ability to pay will be considered. Penalties for violations under this subsection are based on factors like seriousness of violations, economic benefit, history of violations, good-faith efforts, and ability to pay. Penalties received are deposited into a special fund for licensing and other services. Any ongoing actions or penalties paid under this subsection prevent civil enforcement actions under section 505 of the Act. Citizens have the right to intervene in actions under this subsection. The Administrator shall report annually to Congress on funds deposited into a special fund for licensing and other services, which are available for water remediation and preventive projects at Federal facilities. SEC. 4 amends the definition of "person" in the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include any department, agency, or instrumentality of the United States. SEC. 5 defines "radioactive material." SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include a definition of "radioactive material" as source materials, special nuclear materials, and byproduct materials used outside Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensed facilities.
